THIS IS AN EARLY MODEL (ONE OF BAUM'S FIRST) OF THE 'NEW' SIMPLE AND INEXPENSIVE FOLDERS DESIGNED FOR THE PRINTING OFFICE. BAUM FOLDERS COMBINED KNIFE & BUCKLE FOLDING METHODS.
USED IN THE PERTH COURIER OFFICE, PERTH, ONTARIO
From CA of 10/28/1994 by Tony Missio: Undetermined
GRAY PAINT OVER ORIGINAL BLACK FINISH

PTS: A BOX OF MACHINE PARTS/ ORIGINALLY BAUM FOLDERS WERE PRODUCED BY THE LIBERTY FOLDER CO., BUT BY 1925, BAUM BEGAN TO SUPPLY ITS FOLDERS DIRECTLY FROM ITS OWN FACTORIES. THE 19X25 MODEL WAS CALLED 'THE GREATEST VALUE IN THE FOLDER WORLD' IN PERIOD ADVERTISEMENTS/ APPEARS TO MAKE TWO PARALLEL AND ONE RIGHT ANGLE FOLD SERVICE AT THE COURIER OFFICE
2) INLAND PRINTER, V. 77, JULY 1926, P. 523 (SEE SUPP. INFO.)
Clean; treat corrosion; consolidate flaking paint.
Loose dust & dirt brushed & vacuumed off.
CAST IRON FRAMEWORK/ STEEL ROLLERS, GEARS ETC/ SOME BRASS (ROLLER SLEEVES, ETC.)

Deterioration Notes: Compact brown corrosion or relatively uncorroded surfaces on unpainted steel areas; no evident active corrosion. Paint is dirty & oil-stained but mostly intact. Paint losses & flaking from bars on outside of frame holding wooden slat table & on top of mounting lug for fence at side of table near switch; crusty orange-brown ferrous corrosion on exposed metal. One cloth belt is broken, tied to machine. General heavy accretion of dirt & dust; thick greasy dust in recessed areas.

THE SHEET STOPPING MECHANISM OR 'GATE' ON THIS MACHINE WAS INVENTED BY A CANADIAN, E. BLACKHALL OF TORONTO, IN 1870. THIS IMPROVEMENT WAS A MAJOR STAGE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF PEN RULING EQUIPMENT & WAS USEDIN ALL SUCH MACHINERY UNTIL ITS OBSOLESENCE IN THE 1970'S.
TO MECHANICALLY RULE PAPER, CARD STOCK ETC. FOR WRITING, ACCOUNTING OR RECORD-KEEPING PURPOSES.
COULD BE CONSIDERED THE 'STANDARD' FORM OF PEN RULING MACHINE, DESIGNED FOR A VARIETY OF JOB WORK & EMPLOYING AN AUTOMATIC STRIKER (THE FIRST AUTO STRIKER USED 1874).
USED AT LOWE-MARTIN PRINTING CO. IN OTTAWA
VIRTUALLY COMPLETE, FOR LIST OF MACHINE PARTS AS ORIG. SHIPPED IN 1913, SEE SUPP. INFO.

Deterioration Notes: .1: Finish on handle extensively checked but intact. Copper ferrule slightly oxidized but relatively bright, retains copper colour. Ends of bristles greasy & dusty. .2: About 90% loss of finish from handle; remaining finish at end of handle extensively & minutely checked. Numerous fine cracks in handle behind ferrule. Two large splits in ferrule from front to within several mm of back (handle) edge; several other small cracks at front edge. Heavily ink stained overall.
TO CONTAIN INK USED IN RULING MACHINES. FLANNELS & YARN ARE SOAKED IN INK IN BOWL BEFORE BEING PLACED ON MACHINE, EXTRA INK FROM THE BOWL IS ADDED TO FLANNELS WITH BRUSH AS NEEDED DURING OPERATION.

Deterioration Notes: .1: Crusty orange ferrous corrosion on about 20% of ferrule, heaviest at handle end but also concentrated at bristle end. Handle ink-stained. .2: Heavily used & ink-stained overall but no apparent subsequent deterioration. .3: Numerous fine cracks in handle, some cross-grain checking as well. Handle loose in ferrule. Aluminium ferrule heavily pitted & corroded at bristle end, missing 60% of portion around base of bristles; missing bristles from this area as well, about 25% of total. Ink-stained overall. .4: Heavily worn from use. Two plugs of bristles & most of a third broken off at base; bristles dusty.

Loose dust & dirt brushed & vacuumed off.

Deterioration Notes: Joints in carcass are loose, carcass is wobbly. Adhesive on cloth tape holding aluminium & cardboard sheets to top has dried out, tape remains adhered to sheets but not to cabinet. Aluminium sheet scratched & dented. Some paint losses on front half of top, appears to be from prior heat or chemical damage; paint lifting around edges of areas of loss. Also cracks in paint along grain lines in this area due to shrinkage of wood. Dark brown patina on drawer pulls. General dusty, dirty accretion.
NONE SPECIFICALLY. THIS TYPE OF EQUIPMENT WIDELY USED ACROSS CANADA

USED TO "BUNDLE" OR COMPRESS PRINTED SIGNATURES. BUNDLES OF FOLDED SHEETS ARE PLACED BETWEEN THE "HEADS" OF THE PRESS. UNDER PRESSURE, THEY ARE TIED, ACCESS BEING MADE THROUGH LARGE HOLES IN THE HEADS. SIGNATURES ARE THEREBY KEPT CLEAN AND SAFE FROM LOSS UNTIL REQUIRED FOR GATHERING AND BINDING
STANDARD TECHNOLOGY USED IN SMALLER PRINTING FIRMS TO DO LIMITED BINDERY WORK FROM THE LATE 19C THROUGH THE FIRST HALF OF THE 20C.
THIS ONE USED IN OTTAWA ON AT KALADAR ST. IN 'THE RUNGE PRESS'
THIN GOLD LINE ON SIDE SUPPORTS

TYPICAL OFEARLY STYLE RULING MACHINE USED IN CANADA AND SPECIFICALLY BY A GUELPH BINDERY FROM THE 1850'S UNTIL 1978.
FOR THE RULING OF LINES ON BLANK PAPER (LEDGERS, SCHOOL BOOKS ETC.)

A VERY EARLY STYLE OF RULING MACHINE (CA. 1852) 'THE MACHINE STILL HAS TO BE OPERATED BY HAND & IT WAS STILL NECESSARY TO STOP & START IT IN ORDER TO "SET" THE PEN AT ANY GIVEN POINT ON THE PAPER, BUT INSTEAD OF A SINGLE CLOTH CONVEYOR, IT WAS EQUIPPED WITH TWO CLOTHS..., WHICH PERMITTED THE RULED SHEETS TO DRY AS THEY PASSED THROUGH THE MACHINE & TO BE LAYED AUTOMATICALLY AT THE END IN A RECEIVING BOX, THUS, ELIMINATING THE SERVICES OF THE "LAY-BOY" (REF.1,PG.5).
GUELPH, ONTARIO, GUELPH BINDERY 1857-1883; NUNEN BINDERY CA. 1883-1978

THIS IS A VERY COMMONSTYLE OF STANDING PRESS, THE DESIGN PROBABLY HAVING BEEN 'BORROWED' FROM AN AMERICAN PATTERN, HOWEVER MFRS. WERE PERHAPS THE ONLY REGISTERED MFR'S OF SUCH PRESSES IN THE 19TH & PERHAPS EVEN THE 20TH CENTURIES.
FOR COMPRESSING BOOKS AFTER ASSEMBLY. BASICALLY TO 'FLATTEN' BOOKS AFTER FINISHING THEREBY PROVIDING 'SOLIDITY' TO VOLUMES BY COMPRESSING PAGES, SMOOTHING COVERS, ETC.

A MANUAL STYLE OF STANDING PRESS EMPLOYING A 'SPIDER' AND IRON LEVER TO OBTAIN PRESSURE ON THE PLATEN. PRESSING WAS DONE BEFORE SEWING IN HAND BOUND BOOKS & AFTER IT IN MACHINE SEWN VOLUMES. PRESSING BROUGHT THE LEAVES IN PERFECT CONTACT EVEN TO THE EXTENT OF CAUSING THE GRAIN OF THE PAPER TO FIT TOGETHER (2). THIS WAS NOT A DESIRABLE FEATURE ON SOME SPECIAL PAPERS & COULD ALSO CAUSE 'OFF-SETTING' ON OTHERS. PRESSING IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT FOR HALF-BOUND BOOKS SO THAT THE JOINS OF THE LEATHER & SIDING MATERIAL ARE FLATTENED & 'MERGE'. STANDING PRESSES WERE ALSO USED TO OBTAIN A DESIRED FINISH ON GRAIN LEATHER COVERS. SINCE PRESSING IS GENERALLY DONE OVER A PERIOD OF DAYS OR EVEN WEEKS, THE VOLUMES WILL DRY OUT (AFTER THE DAMPENING EFFECT OF THE BINDING PROCESS) UNDER PRESSURE SO THAT THE FORM ACQUIRED DURING PRESSING IS PERMANENT.

Stable Comments: Corrosion on underside of platen may be active; check for recurrence in one year. :: Deterioration Notes: Very dirty overall; opaque, flaking layer over paint may be dirt or a deteriorated clear coating e.g.. varnish. Extensive paint loss from the four upright rods, crusty orange-brown ferrous corrosion on exposed metal. Thick dirty oil on screw; paint on spokes with handles for raising & lowering platen also oily. Powdery white crystalline deposits on ribs an top of platen. Fine powdery orange ferrous corrosion general on underside of platen with denser spots of similar corrosion covering about 50% of the surface. Stable gray patina over most of surface of bed, orange ferrous corrosion at ends. Steel strips at edges of plywood boards covered in ferrous corrosion to varying degrees.
GUILLOTINE TYPE CUTTER USED TO CUT BULK PAPER STOCK. THE BLADE BEING ACTIVATED BY A HAND TURNED FLY-WHEEL.

THERE WERE, IN THE 19TH C., BASICALLY TWO TYPES OF HAND OPERATED CUTTERS- LEVER & FLYWHEEL- MOST CUTTERS WERE VARIATIONS OF THESE TWO METHODS. THIS FLYWHEEL CUTTER WAS DESIGNED FOR HAND OPERATION ONLY & GEARED SO THAT THE GUILLOTINE CUT CAN BE ACCOMPLISHED EASILY.
COMPLETE (DISASSEMBLED FOR SHIPPING - TO BE REBUILT)

PAINTED BLACK- SOMESMOKE & EXTINGUISHING FOAM DAMAGE/ ORIGINAL FINISH OF ONE SECTION OF FRAME CROSS BRACING WAS COMPLETELY REMOVED IN THE SUMMER OF 1979 FOR THE PURPOSE OF AN 'ART FORM EXHIBIT'. SINCE THE APPEARANCE OF THIS SECTION CANNOT BE MADE COMPATABILE TO THE ORIGINAL APPERANCE OF THE CUTTER, THE ENTIRE ARTIFACT WILL HAVE TO BE REFINISHED PRIOR TO ASSEMBLY.

BROWN & CARVER CUTTERS WERE MFR'D & SOLD BY OSWEGO COMMENCING IE 1893 (INLAND PRINTER, V.11, 1893, P.42). THE EARLIEST REFERENCE FOUND IN INLAND PRINTER TO DATE HAS BEEN 1906 FOR THE HAND-WHEEL DRIVE CUTTER/ SUPPLIED BY 'BRITISH TYPE FOUNDERS AGENCY LTD., 70 PEARL ST., TORONTO'/ CW SUPPLEMENTARY BLADE, BLADE SHARPENER, CUTTINGS STICKS (6)/ N.B. POSSIBLY THE ONLY STYLE OF PONY PAPER CUTTER MANUFACTURED IN CANADA.
FOR CUTTING OF SMALLER SIZES OF PAPER & CARDSTOCK

THIS STYLE OF CUTTER THOUGHT TO HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AROUND 1888 BY THE SHNEIDEWEND & LEE CO. OF CHICAGO, THIS CUTTER WAS DESIGNED FOR USE IN A JOB OFFICE & PARTICULARLY FOR CUTTING OF WRITING STOCK (BILLHEADS, NOTE PAPER,CARDS, ETC). ITS SMALL SIZE MADE IT PARTICULARLY POPULAR IN SHOPS WHOSE REQUIREMENTS DID NOT INCLUDE THE CUTTING OF LARGER SIZES OF PAPER. THE W & B CUTTER IS BUILT VIRTUALLY IDENTICALLY TO THE CHALLENGE PONY CUTTER MFG BY SHNEIDEWEND & LEE.

WESTMAN & BAKER WAS AN IMPORTANT CANADIAN MFR OF PRINTING & BOOKBINDING EQ., AND LIKELY THE ONLY COMPANY IN CANADA TO PRODUCE BACKING MACHINES DURING THE PERIOD 1890-1922. THEIR PRODUCTS COMPETED FAVOURABLY WITH US AND FOREIGN GOODS, AND WERE DISTRIBUTED BY TORONTO TYPE FOUNDARY (TORONTO,MONTREAL, WINNIPEG, VANCOUVER, AS WELL AS OTHER LARGE PRINTING SUPPLY HOUSES IN CANADA. (REF. 1)
USED TO SHAPE A RIDGE OR SHOULDER ON EACH SIDE OF THE SPINE OF A BOOK, BEFORE THE APPLICATION OF SPINE LINING MATERIAL.

ROUNDING OF BOOK BACKS PROBABLY WAS NOT POPULAR UNTIL AFTER 1500: UNTIL 1850S A "VICE" AND HAMMER WERE STANDARD TOOLS. IN MID 19TH C. MANUAL BACKERS WERE DEV'D, & THEIR USE CONTINUES. BACKERS ARE USED EXTENSIVELY BY CRAFT BINDERS, AND SOME COMMERCIAL BINDERIES WHERE MORE CONTROL OVER WORK IS REQUIRED. TODAY, IN BOTH EDITION AND LIBRARY BINDING, THE MOST COMMON METHOD IS TO ROUND AND BACK BOOKS IN 2 CONSECUTIVE OPERATIONS IN A ROUNDING & BACKING MACHINE. (REF. 2)
THIS TYPE OF PRESS USED C. MID 19TH C. TO PRESENT.
THIS TYPE OF PRESS USED IN CANADA & USA; POSSIBLY ALSO ELSEWHERE.
BLACK ENAMEL FINISH ON ALL SURFACES, SAVE VICE FACES AND THREADED SHAFT.

Standard type of standing press used in mid to late 19th century small-production Canadian binderies.
Applies pressure to newly bound books to allow glue which holds case (cover) and book together to dry.
This model represents the "traditional" manually operated style of standing press which is still popular with craft binderies. The iron press superceded one with wood checks.
